advantages: Parallelism: Multiple queues allow simultaneous processing of different tasks, increasing throughput.
Task segregation: Can be used to separate tasks into different queues based on their type or priority.
Improved scalability: More queues allow for more parallel operations, improving the system's scalability.
disadvantages: Management complexity: Handling multiple queues requires careful monitoring and synchronization to prevent issues.
Increased overhead: Maintaining multiple queues requires more resources, potentially slowing down the system.
Uneven load: If tasks are not distributed evenly, some queues may become overloaded while others are underutilized.
